author: liquan.eth
content:
https://ethereum.org/en/glossary/#zero-address
One question, is the description of zero address wrong here?
Personally, if a transaction initiated by EOA is trying to create a smart contract, then the `to` of this `transaction` needs to be set to `None`. If it is a certain address, EVM will try to transfer the `value` into this address and try to execute the smart contract in this address according to `transaction.data`, no matter whether this address is a zero address or not.

author: joeysantoro
content: The description is correct. The zero address has a special functionality where the output of the calldata sent to this address becomes a new smart contract deployed at the address derived from the next nonce of the sender

author: ralexstokes
content: <@400852623512698881> <@533350294059352074> i'd say this is incorrect; the contract creation address is "empty", represented as "null" or "nil" depending on your representation; the `0x0000...0000` address is a valid address w/ no special semantics, other than it is very likely no one has the private key, so we can use it as a bit of a burn address

author: ralexstokes
content: and just to clarify, for contract creation, the calldata becomes "init-time" code that is executed and the *output* of that execution becomes the "runtime" smart contract code that lives on chain

author: joeysantoro
content: If you send a transaction with calldata to 0x0, does it not make a new contract?

author: ralexstokes
content:
ethereum's state is currently structured as a mapping of 20-byte "addresses" to accounts

so `0x0` as a nibble doesn't really make sense to refer to an account

there is the 20-byte string of all zero-bytes `0x00...00` which is a valid account that has no special semantics

to create a contract via an EOA transaction, you can send some bytecode to the "empty" address, which can be serialized as `0x` (aka no bytes)

if you see `0x0` somewhere id say that is an abuse of notation somewhere bc then upstream consumers of that data have to special-case this thing, a better way to represent in the JSON context imo is w/ JSON's `null`

author: ralexstokes
content: you can check the yellow paper where they have a `B_0` formalism and you can see the relevant spec here: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/blob/7d6a46800a2614227d7324d5c172c4cfeaedf737/src/ethereum/frontier/vm/interpreter.py#L83
